body: That happens only if no GOPATH is set I think.

@AudriusButkevicius as you can see in the install method above, we explicitly set GOPATH:
```
ENV["GOPATH"] = buildpath/".syncthing-gopath"
```

This is not GOPATH, this is building the standard library with an install suffix based on tags. This is the Go compiler wanting to write object files.

The build script sets an install suffix based on tags as this allows compiled objects to coexist for regular, race detector, noupgrade, etc type builds.

I have a similar issue:

```
go run build.go -no-upgrade -version v0.14.33 build
runtime/internal/sys
go install runtime/internal/sys: mkdir /usr/lib/go/pkg/linux_amd64_noupgrade: permission denied
```
GOPATH is set

```
export GOPATH="$Fsrcdir"
```
@calmh it seems the noupgrade tag propagates to runtime somehow as `linux_amd64_noupgrade` doesn't look right.

I can also reproduce this using fakeroot in solbuild (an isolated, chroot environment) for Solus (Linux). We set a GOPATH (GOPATH=/home/build/YPKG/root/syncthing/build), this has worked in prior releases of syncthing, however now I get the identical issue to @DeX77:

```
+ go run build.go -no-upgrade -version v0.14.33 build                                                                                                                                                  
runtime/internal/sys                                                                                                                                                                                   
go install runtime/internal/sys: mkdir /usr/lib64/golang/pkg/linux_amd64_noupgrade: permission denied
```
I can reproduce it on Linux, and presence of `-no-upgrade` option doesn't matter.

Still
```
==> ./build.sh noupgrade
runtime/internal/sys
go install runtime/internal/sys: mkdir /usr/local/Cellar/go/1.8.3/libexec/pkg/darwin_amd64_noupgrade: operation not permitted
exit status 1
exit status 1
```
with 428 deleted

There is also https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/build.go#L407

Will try if removing both of them helps.

I intentionally add the tags as install suffix as this means two successive build server builds can retain and reuse the object files. Unfortunately this apparently also means stdlib needs to be built with that install suffix. I'll change this to an explicit flag instead so it doesn't happen for unaware builders.
